sources: FDA Table of Pharmacogenomic Biomarkers in Drug Labeling

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2D6 converts codeine to morphine (active metabolite). Activity determines analgesic efficacy and toxicity risk.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Greatly reduced conversion to morphine; minimal analgesic effect
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Avoid codeine. Use analgesics not metabolized by CYP2D6 (e.g., morphine, acetaminophen, NSAIDs, or oxycodone with caution).

intermediate_metabolizer.effect: Reduced conversion to morphine; diminished analgesic effect likely
intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Use alternative analgesic if possible. If codeine is used, monitor closely for inadequate pain relief.
intermediate_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Reduced efficacy; may require dose escalation or switch

normal_metabolizer.effect: Expected conversion to morphine; standard analgesic response

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.effect: Greatly increased conversion to morphine; risk of life-threatening respiratory depression and toxicity
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: AVOID codeine. Use analgesics not metabolized by CYP2D6. Risk of fatal respiratory depression.
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Life-threatening toxicity; morphine accumulation; respiratory depression; death reported

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2D6 and Codeine Therapy (2019 Update)
references: Crews KR, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2021;109(4):867-878
FDA Drug Safety Communication: Codeine use in children (2017)

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2D6 converts tramadol to O-desmethyltramadol (active metabolite with higher mu-opioid affinity).

poor_metabolizer.effect: Reduced formation of active metabolite; reduced analgesic efficacy
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider alternative analgesic. If tramadol required, monitor for inadequate pain control.

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Use standard dose with monitoring for efficacy.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.effect: Increased active metabolite; risk of respiratory depression and seizures
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: AVOID tramadol. Risk of life-threatening toxicity. Use alternative analgesic.
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Respiratory depression; seizure risk; potential fatality

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2D6 and Codeine Therapy (applies to tramadol)
references: Crews KR, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2021;109(4):867-878

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2D6 converts oxycodone to oxymorphone (active metabolite), though parent compound also has analgesic activity.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Reduced oxymorphone formation; modestly reduced overall analgesic effect
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Use standard dose; monitor for pain control. Parent compound retains activity.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.effect: Increased oxymorphone formation; potential for increased opioid effects
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Use with caution; consider lower starting dose with careful titration.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2D6 and Opioid Therapy
references: Crews KR, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2021;109(4):867-878

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2C19 is primary enzyme for citalopram demethylation. Metabolizer status affects plasma levels and adverse effect risk.

poor_metabolizer.effect: ~2-fold increase in plasma concentrations; increased risk of QTc prolongation and side effects
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce dose by 50% (max 20 mg/day) OR switch to alternative SSRI not predominantly metabolized by CYP2C19 (e.g., sertraline, fluoxetine).
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: QTc prolongation; serotonin syndrome risk; increased side effects

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider dose reduction to 75% of standard dose or use alternative SSRI.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.effect: Greatly reduced plasma concentrations; likely therapeutic failure
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider alternative SSRI not predominantly metabolized by CYP2C19 (e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline) OR increase dose with therapeutic drug monitoring.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2C19 and CYP2D6 Genotypes and SSRIs/SNRIs (2023 Update)
references: Bousman CA, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2023;114(1):51-68
FDA Label: Celexa (citalopram) - CYP2C19 poor metabolizer information

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2C19 is primary enzyme for escitalopram metabolism. S-enantiomer of citalopram with same metabolic pathway.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Significantly elevated plasma concentrations; QTc prolongation risk
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce dose by 50% (max 10 mg/day) OR switch to alternative SSRI (sertraline, fluoxetine).

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider dose reduction to 75% of standard or use alternative SSRI.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Switch to alternative SSRI (sertraline, fluoxetine) not dependent on CYP2C19.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2C19 and CYP2D6 Genotypes and SSRIs/SNRIs (2023 Update)
references: Bousman CA, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2023;114(1):51-68

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2C19 is a secondary pathway for sertraline metabolism. Multiple enzymes involved; less CYP2C19-dependent than citalopram.

poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider 25% dose reduction or standard dose with monitoring.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Use standard dose; consider increase if inadequate response. Sertraline less affected by CYP2C19 status.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2C19 and CYP2D6 Genotypes and SSRIs/SNRIs (2023 Update)
references: Bousman CA, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2023;114(1):51-68

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2D6 is the primary enzyme for nortriptyline hydroxylation. Metabolizer status strongly affects drug levels and toxicity risk.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Greatly elevated plasma concentrations; high risk of cardiac and anticholinergic toxicity
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce dose by 50% and use therapeutic drug monitoring. Consider alternative antidepressant.
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Cardiac arrhythmia; anticholinergic toxicity; seizure risk

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce dose by 25% with therapeutic drug monitoring.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Avoid nortriptyline. Use alternative antidepressant not metabolized by CYP2D6.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2D6 and CYP2C19 Genotypes and Tricyclic Antidepressants (2016)
references: Hicks JK, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2017;102(1):37-44

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2C19 is essential for bioactivation of clopidogrel prodrug to active thiol metabolite. Poor metabolizers cannot activate the drug.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Greatly reduced active metabolite formation; inadequate platelet inhibition
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: AVOID clopidogrel. Use prasugrel or ticagrelor (not dependent on CYP2C19 activation).
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Stent thrombosis; myocardial infarction; stroke; cardiovascular death

intermediate_metabolizer.effect: Reduced active metabolite formation; diminished antiplatelet effect
intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Switch to prasugrel or ticagrelor, especially for ACS/PCI patients.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.effect: Increased active metabolite formation; enhanced antiplatelet effect
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Use standard dosing. Monitor for increased bleeding risk.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2C19 and Clopidogrel Therapy (2022 Update)
references: Lee CR, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2022;112(5):959-967
FDA Boxed Warning: Plavix (clopidogrel) - CYP2C19 poor metabolizers

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: VKORC1 encodes vitamin K epoxide reductase, the direct target of warfarin. Variants affect warfarin sensitivity and dose requirements.

high_sensitivity.effect: Greatly increased warfarin sensitivity; low-dose requirement (typically 0.5-2 mg/day)
high_sensitivity.recommendation: Reduce starting dose significantly (1-2 mg/day). Use pharmacogenomic dosing algorithm. Monitor INR closely (every 2-3 days initially).

moderate_sensitivity.effect: Increased warfarin sensitivity; lower dose requirement
moderate_sensitivity.recommendation: Reduce starting dose to 3-4 mg/day. Use pharmacogenomic dosing algorithm. Monitor INR at least weekly initially.
moderate_sensitivity.clinical_consequence: Bleeding risk if standard doses used

normal_sensitivity.recommendation: Use standard dosing algorithm (typically 5 mg/day starting dose).

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for Pharmacogenetics-Guided Warfarin Dosing (2017 Update)
references: Johnson JA, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2017;102(3):397-404
FDA Label: Coumadin (warfarin) - Pharmacogenomic dosing table

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2C9 is the primary enzyme for S-warfarin metabolism (the more potent enantiomer). Reduced function variants decrease warfarin clearance.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Greatly reduced S-warfarin clearance; 50-80% dose reduction typically needed
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce starting dose to 1-2 mg/day. Use pharmacogenomic dosing algorithm incorporating both CYP2C9 and VKORC1 status. Frequent INR monitoring essential.

intermediate_metabolizer.effect: Reduced S-warfarin clearance; lower maintenance dose needed
intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce starting dose to 3-4 mg/day. Use pharmacogenomic dosing algorithm. Monitor INR closely.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for Pharmacogenetics-Guided Warfarin Dosing (2017 Update)
references: Johnson JA, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2017;102(3):397-404

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: SLCO1B1 encodes hepatic uptake transporter OATP1B1. Reduced function increases systemic statin exposure and myopathy risk.

poor_function.effect: Greatly increased simvastatin acid plasma concentrations; high myopathy risk
poor_function.recommendation: AVOID simvastatin. Use rosuvastatin or pravastatin (less SLCO1B1-dependent). If statin needed, use low-dose rosuvastatin or pravastatin.

intermediate_function.effect: Increased simvastatin exposure; elevated myopathy risk
intermediate_function.recommendation: Avoid simvastatin doses >20 mg/day OR switch to rosuvastatin or pravastatin.
intermediate_function.clinical_consequence: Myopathy risk; muscle pain; CK elevation

normal_function.effect: Normal hepatic uptake and statin clearance

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for SLCO1B1, ABCG2, and CYP2C9 and Statin-Associated Musculoskeletal Symptoms (2022)
references: Cooper-DeHoff RM, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2022;111(5):1007-1021
SEARCH Collaborative Group. Lancet. 2008;372(9635):270-278

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: SLCO1B1 mediates hepatic uptake of atorvastatin. Reduced function modestly increases systemic exposure.

poor_function.effect: Increased atorvastatin exposure; elevated but lower myopathy risk than simvastatin
poor_function.recommendation: Use atorvastatin <=40 mg/day with monitoring for muscle symptoms. Consider rosuvastatin or pravastatin if symptoms develop.

intermediate_function.recommendation: Use standard dosing with routine muscle symptom monitoring.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for SLCO1B1 and Statins (2022)
references: Cooper-DeHoff RM, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2022;111(5):1007-1021

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2D6 converts tamoxifen to endoxifen (primary active metabolite with ~100x greater anti-estrogenic potency).

poor_metabolizer.effect: Greatly reduced endoxifen formation; compromised anti-tumor efficacy
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: AVOID tamoxifen. Switch to aromatase inhibitor (if postmenopausal) or consider higher tamoxifen dose (40mg) with endoxifen level monitoring.
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Increased breast cancer recurrence risk; treatment failure

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider aromatase inhibitor (if postmenopausal) or increase tamoxifen to 40 mg/day with endoxifen monitoring.
intermediate_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Reduced anti-tumor efficacy; higher recurrence risk

normal_metabolizer.effect: Adequate endoxifen formation; expected therapeutic benefit

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.effect: Increased endoxifen formation; enhanced efficacy possible
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Use standard dosing. May have enhanced therapeutic benefit.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2D6 and Tamoxifen Therapy (2018)
references: Goetz MP, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2018;103(5):770-777

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: DPYD encodes dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD), responsible for >80% of 5-FU catabolism. Deficiency causes life-threatening toxicity.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Complete or near-complete DPD deficiency; 5-FU accumulation to lethal levels
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: 5-FU and capecitabine are CONTRAINDICATED. Use alternative chemotherapy regimen. DPD deficiency is potentially fatal.
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Fatal toxicity: severe mucositis, myelosuppression, neurotoxicity, death

intermediate_metabolizer.effect: Partial DPD deficiency; significantly increased toxicity risk
intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce 5-FU/capecitabine dose by 50%. Monitor closely for toxicity. Increase dose only if tolerated after 2+ cycles.
intermediate_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Severe toxicity: neutropenia, mucositis, diarrhea, hand-foot syndrome

normal_metabolizer.recommendation: Use label-recommended dosing based on BSA.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for DPYD Genotype and Fluoropyrimidine Dosing (2017)
references: Amstutz U, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2018;103(2):210-216
EMA Recommendation: DPD testing before fluoropyrimidine treatment (2020)

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: Capecitabine is an oral prodrug of 5-FU. Same DPD-dependent catabolism pathway applies.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Complete or near-complete DPD deficiency; lethal toxicity expected
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Capecitabine is CONTRAINDICATED. Use alternative chemotherapy.

intermediate_metabolizer.effect: Partial DPD deficiency; significantly increased toxicity
intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce capecitabine dose by 50%. Monitor closely for toxicity signs.

normal_metabolizer.recommendation: Use label-recommended dosing based on BSA.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for DPYD and Fluoropyrimidines (2017)
references: Amstutz U, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2018;103(2):210-216

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: UGT1A1 glucuronidates SN-38 (active metabolite of irinotecan). Reduced activity leads to SN-38 accumulation and severe toxicity.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Greatly increased SN-38 exposure; severe neutropenia and diarrhea
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce irinotecan dose by 30% for UGT1A1 *28/*28 (homozygous). Monitor closely for neutropenia and severe diarrhea.
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Severe neutropenia; life-threatening diarrhea; sepsis risk

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider dose reduction in high-dose regimens (>250 mg/m2). Standard dosing may be acceptable in lower-dose regimens with monitoring.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: PharmGKB Clinical Annotation for UGT1A1 and Irinotecan
references: FDA Label: Camptosar (irinotecan) - UGT1A1*28 dosing guidance
Innocenti F, et al. J Clin Oncol. 2009;27(16):2604-2614

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: TPMT methylates thiopurines to inactive metabolites. Deficiency leads to accumulation of cytotoxic thioguanine nucleotides.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Complete TPMT deficiency; massive accumulation of active thioguanine nucleotides
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce dose to 10% of standard. Consider 3x weekly dosing instead of daily. Mandatory TGN level monitoring.

intermediate_metabolizer.effect: Reduced TPMT activity; increased TGN accumulation
intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce dose by 30-50%. Monitor TGN levels and CBC closely.

normal_metabolizer.recommendation: Use label-recommended dosing with standard TGN monitoring.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for TPMT/NUDT15 and Thiopurines (2018)
references: Relling MV, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2019;105(5):1095-1105

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2D6 metabolizes ondansetron. Ultra-rapid metabolizers may have reduced antiemetic efficacy.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Increased ondansetron exposure; potentially enhanced antiemetic effect
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Use standard dosing. May have enhanced antiemetic effect.
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Potentially enhanced efficacy; minimal clinical concern

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.effect: Increased ondansetron clearance; reduced antiemetic efficacy
ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: Consider alternative antiemetic (granisetron) not primarily metabolized by CYP2D6.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2D6 and Ondansetron/Tropisetron (2021)
references: Bell GC, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2017;101(2):234-237

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP3A4 and CYP3A5 are primary enzymes for tacrolimus metabolism. CYP3A5 expressors require higher doses to achieve therapeutic levels.

poor_metabolizer.effect: Reduced tacrolimus metabolism; elevated trough levels
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Reduce starting dose by 30-50%. Monitor trough levels closely (target 5-15 ng/mL depending on indication).

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Use standard starting dose with close trough level monitoring. Adjust based on therapeutic drug monitoring.

normal_metabolizer.recommendation: Use label-recommended dosing with standard TDM.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP3A5 and Tacrolimus (2015)
references: Birdwell KA, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2015;98(1):19-24

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: HLA-B*15:02 allele is strongly associated with carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

hla_b_1502_positive.effect: High risk of SJS/TEN (up to 5% in carriers vs <0.01% in non-carriers)
hla_b_1502_positive.recommendation: CONTRAINDICATED. Do not initiate carbamazepine. Use alternative mood stabilizer (valproate, lamotrigine with HLA testing, lithium).
hla_b_1502_positive.clinical_consequence: Stevens-Johnson syndrome; toxic epidermal necrolysis; potentially fatal

hla_b_1502_negative.effect: Low risk of SJS/TEN from HLA-B*15:02 (other risk factors may still apply)
hla_b_1502_negative.recommendation: Use label-recommended dosing. Note: HLA-A*31:01 also associated with carbamazepine hypersensitivity in European populations.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for HLA-B Genotype and Carbamazepine/Oxcarbazepine (2021)
references: Phillips EJ, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2018;103(4):612-617
FDA Boxed Warning: Tegretol (carbamazepine) - HLA-B*15:02 testing requirement

gene_drug_interactions.mechanism: CYP2D6 is the primary metabolizing enzyme for atomoxetine. Poor metabolizers have ~10-fold higher AUC.

poor_metabolizer.effect: ~10-fold increase in plasma exposure; greatly increased side effects
poor_metabolizer.recommendation: Start at 0.5 mg/kg/day (vs 1.2 mg/kg standard). Titrate slowly. Maximum dose 1.2 mg/kg/day (vs 1.8 mg/kg standard).
poor_metabolizer.clinical_consequence: Cardiovascular side effects; liver toxicity; mood changes

intermediate_metabolizer.recommendation: Start at standard dose; titrate cautiously with monitoring.

ultra_rapid_metabolizer.recommendation: May need higher doses to achieve therapeutic effect. Monitor for efficacy.

gene_drug_interactions.cpic_guideline: CPIC Guideline for CYP2D6 and Atomoxetine (2019)
references: Brown JT, et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2019;106(1):94-102
